awd_titl_txt: Purchase of a Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectrometer
awd_abstract_narration: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is the most                       powerful tool available to the chemist for the elucidation of                   the structure of molecules.  It is used to identify unknown                     substances, characterize specific arrangements of atoms within                  molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between                    molecules in solution.  Access to modern NMR spectroscopy is                    essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research.                                                                                                   The Department of Chemistry at the University of Missouri,                      Columbia, will use this award from the Chemical Instrumentation                 Program to help acquire a high-field NMR spectrometer.  The                     areas of chemical research that will be enhanced by the                         acquisition include the following:                                                                                                                              1) New ozonide chemistry                                                        2) Relationship between kestoses and the biosynthesis of plant                     fructans                                                                     3) Nitrosamine chemistry                                                        4) Late transition metal mu-oxo and mu-imido complexes                          5) Chemical and biosynthetic studies of Fusarium                                6) NMR studies of slow molecular motions in molecular                              aggregates and macromolecules.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
